metadata.title: Fabrication and characterization of electrospun cellulose/nano-hydroxyapatite nanofibers for bone tissue engineering

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Title: Fabrication and characterization of electrospun cellulose/nano-hydroxyapatite nanofibers for bone tissue engineering Author: <ce:author id="aut0005" author-id="S014181301631772X4e67b2c911f853a61669c614b20250d1"> Chenghong Ao<ce:author id="aut0010" author-id="S014181301631772X1fc806f3d2152d6c20d3e7ba93126e8b"> Yan Niu<ce:author id="aut0015" author-id="S014181301631772X33f905470868b58a0d57addf0fdd92c2"> Ximu Zhang<ce:author id="aut0020" author-id="S014181301631772X460b2e2689044dc7ce83dd0ef6256829"> Xu He<ce:author id="aut0025" author-id="S014181301631772Xab19122b23288bb7082afe9c668abf57"> Wei Zhang<ce:author id="aut0030" author-id="S014181301631772Xded70e2a4e2c06afee1feb94311e2ecb"> Canhui Lu PII: S0141-8130(16)31772-X DOI: http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.1016/j.ijbiomac.2016.12.091 Reference: BIOMAC 6950 To appear in: International Journal of Biological Macromolecules Received date: 26-9-2016 Accepted date: 30-12-2016 Please cite this article as: Chenghong Ao, Yan Niu, Ximu Zhang, Xu He, Wei Zhang, Canhui Lu, Fabrication and characterization of electrospun cellulose/nanohydroxyapatite nanofibers for bone tissue engineering, International Journal of Biological Macromolecules http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ijbiomac.2016.12.091
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
Fabrication and characterization of electrospun cellulose/nano-hydroxyapatite nanofibers for bone tissue engineering
Chenghong Aoa, Yan Niua, Ximu Zhangb, Xu Hea, Wei Zhanga,*, Canhui Lua,*
a State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering, Polymer Research Institute at Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China b State Key Laboratory of Oral Disease, West China Hospital of Stomatology, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610041, China
* Corresponding authors. Tel.: +862885460607; fax: +862885402465. E-mail addresses: weizhang@scu.edu.cn (W.Zhang), canhuilu@263.net (C. Lu).
ABSTRACT Nanofibrous scaffolds from cotton cellulose and nano-hydroxyapatite (nano-HA) were electrospun for bone tissue engineering. The solution properties of cellulose/nano-HA spinning dopes and their associated electrospinnability were characterized. Morphological, thermal and mechanical properties of the electrospun cellulose/nano-HA nanocomposite nanofibers (ECHNN) were measured and the biocompatibility of ECHNN with human dental follicle cells (HDFCs) was evaluated. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images indicated that the average diameter of ECHNN increased with a higher nano-HA loading and the fiber diameter distributions were well within the range of natural ECM (extra cellular matrix) fibers (50-500 nm). The ECHNN exhibited extraordinary mechanical properties with a tensile strength and a Young’s modulus up to 70.6 MPa and 3.12 GPa respectively. Moreover, it was discovered that the thermostability of the ECHNN could be enhanced with the incorporation of nano-HA. Cell culture experiments demonstrated that the ECHNN scaffolds were quite biocompatible for HDFCs attachment and proliferation, suggesting their great potentials as scaffold materials in bone tissue engineering.
Keywords: Cotton cellulose; Electrospinning; Bone tissue engineering.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Millions of people are suffering from bone defects arising from trauma, tumor or bone related diseases and of course some of them are dying every year because of insufficiently ideal bone tissue [1]. When the damage of tissue is severe or disruptive, tissue engineering is considered a promising alternative since it can compensate for the scarcity of donor tissue. In bone tissue engineering, scaffold served as the matrices of tissue formation plays a pivotal role [2]. The scaffolds should mimic the natural extra-cellular matrix (ECM) so that the cells can undergo growth and differentiation to specific tissues as they would have naturally [3]. In addition, an ideal scaffold should have specific properties, such as biocompatibility, high porosity, high surface area, high pore interconnectivity, and excellent mechanical strength to withstand the dynamic remodeling of the engineered bone in vivo [3,4].
Of the various techniques available for scaffolds fabrication, electrospinning is simple and cost-effective for producing scaffolds with high porosity as well as nanoscale matrix features [5]. Specifically, electrospun nanofibers could closely mimic the nanofibrillar components (e.g., collagen) of ECM that naturally surrounds the cells of any biological tissue [6]. Moreover, the nanoscaled surface topography can promote osteoblast adhesion and the high porosity of scaffolds allows many cells accommodated in that form [7].
As one of the world’s most abundant natural and renewable materials, cellulose is low in cost and extensive in source [8]. In particular, its excellent biodegradability and biocompatibility make it being used for recent applications in biomaterials and tissue engineering [9]. Hydroxyapatite (Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2; HA) is the major inorganic component of natural bone and has been applied widely in the biomedical field as bone repair materials because of its excellent bioactivity and biocompatibility [10,11]. However, it is not possible to use HA alone as scaffold materials owing to the defects of brittleness. The combination of biodegradable polymers and bioactive inorganic materials may take advantages of the mechanical properties, biocompatibility and cell affinities of the individual components. A wide variety of composite materials from biopolymers and HA have already been investigated, including bacterial cellulose (BCs)/HA and chitosan/HA, which exhibited strong capability to induce stem cell differentiation to osteocyte [12-14]. However, most of the studies on cellulose were based on either BC or cellulose derivatives. It is well known that cellulose derivatives require complex post-modification processes for
tissue engineering and they are also poor in strength and susceptible to rapid degradation. While the applications of BCs have been limited by the inconsistent structural morphology (fiber diameter, pore size, etc.) and the inability to encapsulate substances [15].
To combine cellulose with nano-HA using electrospinning is considered a reasonable way to generate composite nanofibers with the appropriate properties targeted for bone tissue engineering. In this work, we developed for the first time an effective process to fabricate electrospun cellulose/nano-HA nanocomposite nanofibers (ECHNN) based on native cotton cellulose and nano-HA. The solvent system of LiCl/DMAc, which almost does not generate side reaction [16] and cause degradation of cellulose [17], was adopted for the dissolution of cotton cellulose. The cellulose solutions with well-dispersed nano-HA were prepared as the spinning dope. The solution properties were comprehensively studied and associated with its electrospinnability. The physical properties of ECHNN and their potential application in bone tissue engineering were also assessed. 2. Materials and methods 2.1. Materials
Purified cotton (medical level, Health Materials Co., Ltd., Chengdu, China) was used as the raw material. N, N’- dimethylacetamide (DMAc), methanol and lithium chloride (LiCl) were purchased from Kelong Chemicals Co., Ltd. (Chengdu, China). Nano-HA with particle sizes in the range of 30-50 nm was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All the reagents in this study were of analytical grade and were used without further purification. Distilled water was used throughout the experiment.
2.2. Preparation of cellulose/nano-HA solutions
To dissolve cellulose efficiently, the cotton was activated by immersion in water, methanol and DMAc for 1 h respectively, followed by vacuum filtration. The 8 wt % LiCl/DMAc solvent was prepared as described in literature [18]. Nano-HA with concentrations of 3, 5, and 10% (w/w, in respect to the weight of dissolved cellulose) was added to the 8 wt % LiCl/DMAc solvent respectively. And these suspensions were ultrasonically treated (GY99-IIDN, China) at 200 W for 0.5 h to obtain well-dispersed nano-HA suspensions in LiCl/DMAc solution. Next, 1 g activated cellulose was added in the mixture, which was subjected to magnetic stirring at ambient
conditions until absolutely dissolved.
2.3. Electrospinning process
The detailed electrospinning process can be found in our previous publication [18]. Briefly, the flow rate (0.04 mL/min) of the solution was controlled by a micro pump. The tangential velocity of the rotating metal collector was set at 300 m/min so as to induce the alignment of electrospun nanofibers. The oriented fibers were gained at a high speed due to a centrifugal force was developed near the vicinity of the circumference of the rotating drum, which elongates the fibers before being collected on the drum [19]. The rotating collector was partly immersed in a water coagulation bath to remove the solvent from electrospun fibers and produce well-defined fibers. 2.4. Characterization
The surface tension (γ) of solution was measured by a KRUSS K100 tensiometer in the automatic model of the plate at room temperature. The solution conductivity was measured by a conductivity meter (DDS-11A, Century Ark Technology Co. Chengdu, China) at room temperature. Rheological behaviors were analyzed on a Physica MCR301 rotational rheometer (Anto-Paar, Austria) equipped with concentric cylinder geometry CC27 with a measuring bob radius of 13.33 mm and a measuring cup radius of 14.46 mm. Two types of rheological measurements were carried out: one was oscillatory-shear measurement (frequency sweep tests performed in the linear viscoelastic region, as determined by dynamic strain sweep measurements) and the other was steady-shear-rate scan. The surface morphologies of samples were observed on a field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL JSM-7500F, Japan) at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. Fiber diameter distributions were estimated from the SEM images with the aid of Image J software (at least 100 fibers were randomly selected from the images). The chemical structures of relevant samples were examined by employing an attenuated total reflectance Fourier-transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectrometer. TGA was performed with a TG209 F1 instrument (NETZSCH Co., Germany) to measure the decomposition temperature of ECHNN. The samples were heated from 40 to 600 oC under a nitrogen atmosphere (gas flow rate: 100 mL/min) at a heating rate of 10 oC/min. Tensile strength was measured by an Instron 5567 universal testing machine at a stretching rate of 1 mm/min. The samples were cut by length (along the orientation of fibers) and width (perpendicular to the orientation of fibers) with 30 mm × 10 mm × d mm, where d was the thickness of the samples. The sample’s
thickness was measured using a digital micrometer (MC03000002, Guilin Guanglu Measuring Instrument Co., China) and the result was expressed as the average of 3 random measurements of the sample. 2.5. Cell culture
According to the patients’ panoramic radiographs, normal human impacted third molars (n =10) at root-developing stage were collected from young adult patients ranging in age from 14 to 18 years. Extracted teeth were put into Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM) after washed in PBS for three times. Dental follicle tissues were carefully dissected from the upside of the dental crown and minced into 1 mm3 cubes. These tissue fragments were digested in a solution of 2 ml collagenase type I (1 mg/mL) for 40 min at 37 oC and then terminated by DMEM consisting 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS). Digested tissues were cultured in an incubator (CO2 incubator MCO-175M; Sanyo, Osaka, Japan) with the presence of 5 vol% CO2 in air at 37 oC for 2 h. Then, the standard cell culture medium (low glucose DMEM supplemented with 10% of fetal bovine serum, 2 mM of L-glutamine and 1% of penicillin-streptomycin-amphotericin (PSA) solution) was added. The cultures were maintained at 37 oC in a humidified atmosphere of 5 vol% CO2. Cell culture medium was refreshed every 3 days. After 14 days culture, cell populations were 80% confluent. For the experiments cells of passage 3 were used.
2.6. Cell viability
The ECHNN scaffolds used in this study were cut into squares of 1 cm2 in area. Before seeding cells, the scaffolds were soaked in ethanol with concentrations (75%, v/v) for 1 h. Then, both sides of the scaffolds were treated with UV to ensure the proper sterilization. Subsequently, the scaffolds were washed with 0.1 M PBS (pH 7.4) for three times to remove the traces of ethanol and then saturated in complete DMEM. Aliquots of 1 ml of cell suspension (1.0×104 cells/mL) was seeded onto the hydrated scaffolds, then placed in 24-well cell culture plates and cultured at 37 oC in humidified 5 vol% CO2 atmosphere. After 3 days, cell-loaded scaffolds were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde. Cell nucleus was marked by NucBlue and cytoplasm was stained by ActinGreen. The samples were observed under a reflective fluorescent microscope (Olympus BX43).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. Evaluation of the solution properties and electrospinnability
The picture of the cellulose/nano-HA solutions were observed (Supporting information, Fig. 1S). Obviously, the transparent solution became translucent as the concentration of nano-HA increased. Nonetheless, no sedimentation was observed for all the samples even after one-day rest, indicating the nano-HA could be well dispersed in these solutions. The highly polar and hydrophilic nano-HA seemed quite compatible with the solvent of LiCl/DMAc as well as the solute cellulose.
Rheological behavior at low frequency is sensitive to the structure of the solution [20]. Fig. 1 shows the plots of storage modulus (G') and loss modulus (G") for the solutions with varied nano-HA content at different frequencies were observed. With more nano-HA in this system, both G' and G" increased, suggesting a higher viscosity and elasticity. The shift of the cross-over point of G' and G" can reflect the change of physical crosslinking degree of the studied system [21]. More specifically, when the dynamic cross-over point shifts to a low frequency, the network created by either chain entanglement or crosslinking becomes tight and strengthened [22]. Herein, the cross-over point remarkably shifted to the low frequency with the increase of nano-HA content, suggesting that an interconnected network between cellulose chains and nano-HA through H-bond interactions had been generated. This would inevitably lead to the increased viscosity of the cellulose/nano-HA system.
The solutions also exhibited a strong shear thinning behavior (Supporting information, Fig. 2S). Under the shear forces, the intramolecular and intermolecular H-bonds either between cellulose chains or between cellulose chains and nano-HA could be damaged, leading to the dramatically decreased viscosity. It is important to understand that at a high shear rate, the viscosities of solutions with different nano-HA content was almost the same due to the strong shear forces.
In regard to the electrospinnability of the composite solutions, it was discovered that all the solutions could be well electrospun. The viscosity, surface tension and conductivity of the spinning dope are known to be the three major factors that can strongly influence the electrospinning process [23]. These parameters were analyzed and the results were listed in (Supporting information,Table 1S). It is clear that the incorporation of nano-HA did not bring notable effect on the surface tension and conductivity except the viscosity. However, as
discussed above, the solutions exhibited strong shear thinning behaviors. During the electrospinning process, the high shear force generated through the narrow tunnel of the steel needle would significantly decrease the viscosity of solutions. As a result, all the extruded solutions from the needle may have similar viscosities. 3.3. Morphology of ECHNN
The morphology of ECHNN was examined with SEM and the images were shown in Fig. 2. For all the samples, the electrospun fibers exhibited obvious alignment due to the application of the high-speed rotating collector, irrespective of the nano-HA content. Most of the fibers were well along the orientation axis (indicated using yellow arrows). However, there were still a few fibers that showed significant angular deviation in alignment. This deviation could be ascribed to the rapid deposition of fibers on the grounded collector, which offered insufficient time to completely release the charge, leading to electrostatic repulsion of fibers depositing and being deposited [24]. With the addition of nano-HA, some irregular flake-like agglomerates randomly knitted over the electrospun fibers could be observed, and the number of agglomerates increased with the increase of nano-HA content.
The fiber diameter distributions of ECHNN with different nano-HA content were depicted in Fig. 3. Neat cellulose fibers had diameters in the range of 100-200 nm. And the addition of nano-HA resulted in a shift of fiber diameters towards a higher range. When the nano-HA concentration was high (10%), there was a broad distribution of fiber diameters ranging from 100 to 500 nm and the majority of fibers had diameters closed to the upper nanometer limit of natural ECM fibers. The increased fiber diameter could be possibly ascribed to the formation of nano-HA agglomerates, which significantly hindered the elongation of the fibers during electrospinning [25]. Nonetheless, the fiber diameter distribution was all within the range of natural ECM fibers (50-500 nm) [26].
3.4. ATR-FTIR analysis of ECHNN
The chemical structure of ECHNN was studied by ATR-FTIR. As showed in Fig. 4, the band in the region from 3500 to 3200 cm-1 is assigned to stretching vibration of -OH group. This band became remarkably broadened and its peak obviously shifted to a higher wavenumber with the increase of nano-HA content, suggesting that numerous H-bonds among cellulose and nano-HA was formed [27]. The band observed for ECHNN at 1032 cm-1 was corresponded to the asymmetric and symmetric modes of the P-O bonds of the
phosphate groups while the bands at 603 and 567 cm-1 were attributed to the bending mode of the O-P-O bonds. And the intensities of these bands increased at a higher nano-HA loading, indicating the presence of PO4 -3 in the ECHNN [28]. The absorption band at 1056 cm-1 was ascribed to the stretching vibrations of C-O-C bond at cellulose chains [29]. This band became broader in ECHNN, which was also consistent with the possible interaction between nano-HA and the cellulose matrix [27].
3.5. TG thermograms of ECHNN
Thermogravimetric analysis was carried out to estimate thermal stability and degradation profiles of ECHNN. The TG curves were presented (Supporting information, Fig. 3S) and the data was summarized in Table 1. All the ECHNN exhibited similar TG profiles. The first weight loss in the temperature range of 50-150 oC was due to the evaporation of water, and the second one between 200 and 400 oC was associated with the decomposition of cellulose matrix. There was no weight loss occurred above 500 oC, suggesting the incorporated nano-HA was thermally stable at high temperatures [30]. In addition, compared with neat cellulose nanofibers, more residues were observed after the thermal degradation of ECHNN, which confirmed the nano-HA deposition in the cellulose matrix [31]. The results also indicated that the thermal stability of neat cellulose nanofibers was greatly improved in the presence of nano-HA. The initial degradation temperature (Ti) and the maximum degradation rate temperature (Td) of 10% ECHNN were 288.5 and 337.3 oC, which were 28.5 and 26.7 oC higher than those of 0% ECHNN (260.5 °C for Ti and 310.6 °C for Td), respectively. The increased thermostability of ECHNN was owing to the strong interaction between cellulose and nano-HA and the later serving as the heat isolator [32]. 3.6. Mechanical properties of ECHNN
The stress/strain curves of the ECHNN were demonstrated (Supporting information, Fig. 4S). And the corresponding values including the maximum tensile stress, Young’s modulus, and elongation at break were summarized in Table 1. All the specimens exhibited brittle facture behaviors without a yielding stage. Notably, the mechanical properties of ECHNN could be highly improved when the nano-HA was low (below 5%). In particular, when the nano-HA loading was 5%, a tensile strength of 70.6 MPa and a Young’s modulus of 3.12 GPa was obtained. These values are distinctively higher than those of neat cellulose nanofiber mat (tensile strength of 52.9 MPa; Young’s modulus of 1.64 GPa), suggesting that the well dispersed nano-HA could strengthen ECHNN. However, when the nano-HA loading was
increased to 10%, the mechanical properties deteriorated, owing to the formation of a large number of nano-HA agglomerates (see Fig. 2d), which functioned as defects in the fibers. It should be noted the mechanical properties of those cotton cellulose based electrospun fibers are far better than those of many commonly used electrospun fibers applied in tissue engineering. For example, the tensile strength and Young’s modulus of electrospun PLA nanofiber mat were only 12.3 and 91.3 MPa in the alignment direction respectively even with an optimized carbon nanotube reinforcement [33]. High mechanical properties of scaffold are desired for tissue engineering, in particular in bone regeneration. From this aspect, the ECHNN prepared in this study was quite promising as it provided great mechanical compatibility with those of natural bone [29].
3.7. Biocompatibility of ECHNN
Human dental follicle cells (HDFCs) were used to evaluate the biocompatibility of various ECHNN. The HDFCs proliferation on ECHNN after a period of 72 h culture was evaluated. For the 3% ECHNN, cells were viable but did not well spread on the scaffold (Fig. 5a). The cell number increased obviously when the nano-HA content was 5% (Fig. 5b) and it continued to increase with the increase of nano-HA content. For the 10% ECHNN, the cells distributed evenly and became confluent on the scaffold. The larger number of proliferated cells on ECHNN with a higher nano-HA loading suggested that the addition of nano-HA could positively affect the cytotoxicity of the scaffold. The ECHNN did not induce toxic effects on HDFCs, proving an excellent platform to support cell growth for bone tissue engineering. This is in agreement with the report that the existence of Ca2+ benefits osteoblast cell grows [34].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
To conclude, we have successfully fabricated a series of electrospun nanofiber scaffolds from native cotton cellulose with different nano-HA concentrations. Morphological investigation indicated that the average fiber diameter increased with the increase of nano-HA content and its distribution was well within the diameter distribution of natural ECM fibers (50-500 nm). The addition of nano-HA could remarkably strengthened ECHNN when its content was relatively low. Particularly, for the 5% ECHNN, the tensile strength and Young’s modulus could be as high as 70.6 MPa and 3.12 GPa, respectively. In vitro cell culture with HDFCs demonstrated that the incorporation
of nano-HA did not bring cytotoxicity to the cellulose scaffolds and could promote cell proliferation. The embodiment of novel nanofibrous structure analogue to nature ECM, high strength as well as excellent biocompatibility would allow the ECHNN a promising candidate for future bone tissue engineering applications.

Hydroxyapatite (Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2; HA) is the major inorganic component of natural bone and has been applied widely in the biomedical field as bone repair materials because of its excellent bioactivity and biocompatibility [10,11].

Hydroxyapatite (Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2; HA) is the major inorganic component of natural bone and has been applied widely in the biomedical field as bone repair materials because of its excellent bioactivity and biocompatibility [10,11].

A wide variety of composite materials from biopolymers and HA have already been investigated, including bacterial cellulose (BCs)/HA and chitosan/HA, which exhibited strong capability to induce stem cell differentiation to osteocyte [12-14].

This deviation could be ascribed to the rapid deposition of fibers on the grounded collector, which offered insufficient time to completely release the charge, leading to electrostatic repulsion of fibers depositing and being deposited [24].

And the intensities of these bands increased at a higher nano-HA loading, indicating the presence of PO4 -3 in the ECHNN [28].
The absorption band at 1056 cm was ascribed to the stretching vibrations of C-O-C bond at cellulose chains [29].
This band became broader in ECHNN, which was also consistent with the possible interaction between nano-HA and the cellulose matrix [27].
There was no weight loss occurred above 500 C, suggesting the incorporated nano-HA was thermally stable at high temperatures [30].

The increased thermostability of ECHNN was owing to the strong interaction between cellulose and nano-HA and the later serving as the heat isolator [32].
